history.content:
I've interviewed for SDE intern at Two Sigma and for full-time quant at Jane Street. Also interviewed for full-time SWE and quant at other firms as well.

I'd say the SDE intern interview felt mostly like any other normal software interview. I had to design a data structure / algorithm to accomplish a given task, I had to code something on the spot to process some hypothetical data, and I had to explain my past experience/projects. SWE interviews at other firms were also typical algorithm questions.

I didn't get that far in my quant interviews at any firm (including Jane Street), but the questions I received in my interviews were game theory questions, pattern recognition, quick mental math, probability, and brain teasers.

If you want to be a quant, there are websites to practice sequence/pattern recognition, quick mental math, probability, and brain teasers. I also recommend the book A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I haven't interviewed at Jane Street or Two Sigma but I would like to give you some feedback as you may (or may not) find it valuable. 

First, Jane Street and Two Sigma are not the same type of firm. While they both take a highly quantitative approach to the market, Two Sigma is a hedge fund and Jane Street is a proprietary trading firm. This means that Two Sigma manages (for the most part) money on behalf of (outside) clients. On the other hand, Jane Street trades (for the most part) their own money. Thus, their place in the market is slightly different. 

Second, I have interviewed at firms such as SIG, DRW, etc. The first student answerer is correct in that those are the type of questions they ask. This is something you will definitely need to prepare for. It is completely unlike any other type of interview. Another good book, in addition to Practical Guide, is Heard on the Street. 

Finally, I have had a lot of success networking with Berkeley alumni who work at these firms. Given Berkeley's distance from New York, Chicago, and other financial hubs, the interest here (in the field) is less than at a school such as MIT. If you demonstrate a clear passion, and at least some knowledge of the subject, they are usually happy to get you that initial interview. 

Best of luck!

Also, since you mentioned "big bucks," the biggest bucks are not being made by the software developers or quantitative researchers (or even traders) at these firms. It's being made by the people at the top of large hedge funds (think Bridgewater) who manage large amounts of money from institutional investors. Yes, BIG money is made from management fees. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I've received an offer from one of the big quant firms for SWE Intern (though I turned it down because I realized I personally find finance to be incredibly toxic), and I can tell you that the process is basically a slightly harder version of a normal tech company interview. You get a coding test (this was pretty hard imo, but that's because the place I got the offer at wasn't expecting anyone to finish), a phone interview with some coding and some theory (I actually got asked to solve an approximation algorithm question), and finally an onsite interview. The onsite consisted of 4 interviews varying between low-level understanding (61C/162 material), algorithms/theory and writing cache-friendly implementations, and some abstract system/network design questions. Also theres a meeting with HR to test your personality. It was definitely harder than places like Google when I did their interviews, but not ridiculously so. Think of it like having the probability distribution of easy - medium - hard questions being more skewed to medium/hard than at a place like Google. Also, I got the sense that my answers were held to a higher standard, especially when I made a mistake or mispoke (correcting yourself and asking questions is important! There were topics like networking which I didn't know, so I made that clear before trying to piece together a solution). Overall, its an interesting experience, but I don't think it requires wayyy more practice than normal tech companies. As a side note, I honestly don't think they pay all that much more at least to start out. The intern offer for the top fintech places are all more or less the same this summer (~12k + housing + benefits), which is way more than tech companies (~7-8k + housing + benefits), but the starting TC is around 225-250kish for all of them all in and around 200-215kish for a good tech company. You'll have to work way harder at a fintech company to impress people and last, and the culture is, in my opinion, toxic enough that I didn't find the whole career path worth the marginal boost in money (I prefer a laid back job). Though thats just my opinion. Hope this helps!

children.subject: Completely a personal thing. I went into it with the idea that quant places really give you the meaningful/difficult work. But compared to tech companies, the culture is definitely more high stress and the people (in my opinion) didn't vibe with me. The toxicity mostly just boils down to stress/the finance vibe bc I'm a very type B person and I don't view career as being my top priority in life at all.
@anon Why is the culture in Fintech toxic? How is that different from other companies? I'm curious.

All the answers above are pretty good. One thing to note is that the same position might be very different, even within the same company. Specifically for software engineering you could just be managing and writing code for the database systems in place, or writing high frequency tradings algorithms; the two positions are very different and require very different skills and obviously one is a lot more important to the money making part of the business. For being a trader, the real question is how much stress can you handle? You're sometimes put in a position where your company can lose a lot of money if you make a dumb choice and it relies on you being smart and sometimes making quick correct decisions. That's just the nature of being a trader.

To prepare for interviews, specifically on the quant side, the best place to start is actually CS70 + EE126 (from the interview I've gotten). They like to ask a lot of probability questions, so make sure you get pretty good at the stuff. Other than basic probability stuff, focus especially on Markov chains and how to do expected values on them. I've gotten several problems in interviews where the solution is to set up a Markov chain and perform calculations on them. Depending on the position and the firm, being able to answer them quickly might also be important (especially so for trading positions). Something I'd recommend doing is taking an old 70 exam and trying them again. You should be able to solve every probability question without struggling too much. There are also a ton of books to prep for these interviews, from what I remembered, none of them particularly that much better just grab one of them and try the problems in it.

I'm pretty interested in 2s/js quant intern roles, what's it like getting to the onsite interview? I did the SWE process this year and it involved a long hackerrank and phone interview

Also how did you study for the interview(s)? I got an A in 126 last semester but I'm not very good at tricky combinatorial questions

There was a technical phone interview and a quick hackerrank. I mainly reviewed core concepts (e.g. 126 and 189 core probability/optimization concepts). Note I had spent some time learning some new statistic stuff (e.g. R-squared, etc) that I thought they would ask me about but that wasn't needed at all - the interviews were nice in the sense that they focussed on the areas I had experience on rather than other topics. If you have any more follow up questions feel free to email me (rishiv@berkeley.edu).

I'd just like to offer a different perspective from someone who was not originally interested in fintech but worked at Two Sigma this past summer in the quant role. 

Interview (for quant role):

- Probability, Optimization, Coding, General thinking/high level questions

- As a whole, taking ee126 and ee189 were the two most important classes that got me past the interview.

- Coding was not an emphasis, but I can imagine that in the software role it would be more emphasized. Note my interview didn't have any real discussion about data-structures, but I do know the software intern roles did have some.

Experience:

- I was very surprised about the company culture considering what other people had said about fintech's culture being toxic. TS's culture was very good. Work-life balance was very chill, I would play chess (with interns and employees) during work hours, and there was an internal company-wide table-tennis competition. The people were all nice, helpful, and ridiculously smart.

- From what I understand having interacted with interns of other fintech companies there (e.g. Jane Street, quant interns in JP Morgan), the culture differs greatly per company. Jane Street interns seemed to have a fun time but there seemed to be a big emphasis in market making / betting (or at least their interns "made markets" all the time). JP Morgan interns had to dress up in suits and seemed astonished when I told them how we played chess during work hours. So I'd suggest researching / asking employees about their company culture before branding all of them as having the same culture.

history.content:
How to get into Two Sigma/Jane Street/FinTech (both intern and full-time new grad)? I hear they pay big bucks plus I have an interest in developing innovations for daytrading and quant trading.

I hear their interview process is not as easy as just algorithms and data strcutures
